item.title: Go Proverbs - Rob Pike
item.description:
A fun talk about go lang proverbs. The proverbs point out some of the mindsets that should be followed during the development of go lang programms.

The speaker is Rob Pike, one of the designers of Go lang.

item.title: LeftPad and Go: can tooling help?
item.description:
Nice article about the mindset of Golang community regarding DRY.

A little copying is better than a little dependency.

The article also promotes a simple tool created by the author to identify small dependencies, DepsCheck. The tool was the first contact of the author with Golang AST (Abstract Syntax Tree), in the article he describes how pleasant was to deal with go/{ast,parser,types,loader} packages. The whole tool was the work of a weekend.

item.title: Draw! NodeJS and Go, Count to 1 Billion With a B!
item.description:
Very nice article comparing performance, latency, memory usage and size between simple web services written in nodejs and golang.

Although the article is titled as a draw it points out by metrics that golang is a winner.

The things that drove my attention are the very low memory footprint of golang and the minimum size of a Docker image running the service. Considering the amount of resources required to develop and run microservices, at least in small / medium companies with limited resources, golang seems to be the best option.

item.title: Is Go an Object Oriented Language?
item.description:
This article was written by Steve Francia, the author of Hugo. Hugo is an amazing static website engine written in Go. As I’m in the process of learning go I decided to look at Steve’s blog posts trying to find more information about both Hugo and Go.

The article tries to list what makes a programming language support OOP design. It points out a brief information about OOP concepts like:

  • Inheritance And Polymorphism;
  • Single & Multiple Inheritance;
  • Subtyping (Polymorphism);
  • Object Composition

The article describes how and which of those concepts Go supports.

Steve, as most part of modern software development communities, considers Inheritance as a bad practice. In order to fundament his opinion Steve quotes James Gosling (Java’s inventor) and mentions that GoF book discusses at length replacing implementation (extends) with interface inheritance (implements).
